sections.title: Stocks: Ownership and Growth
sections.content: When you buy a stock, you purchase an ownership stake in a company. Your return comes from price appreciation and, in some cases, dividends. Stocks historically deliver the highest long-term growth but can swing sharply in the short term. Blue-chip companies behave differently from small-cap innovators, so evaluating business fundamentals matters.

sections.title: Bonds: Lending for Predictable Income
sections.content: A bond is a loan to a government or corporation. In exchange, you receive periodic interest payments and the promise of principal repayment at maturity. Bonds generally move opposite to stocks, cushioning your portfolio during market downturns. Credit quality, duration, and interest rates influence bond performance.

points.title: Mutual Funds
points.description: Actively or passively managed baskets of securities that trade once per day at net asset value.

points.title: Exchange-Traded Funds (ETFs)
points.description: Index-tracking or themed funds that trade like stocks, offering intraday liquidity and lower fees.

points.title: Index Funds
points.description: Passive mutual funds or ETFs that mirror a market benchmark with minimal costs.

sections.title: Blending Asset Types
sections.content: A 70/30 stock-to-bond portfolio historically returned about 9% annually with significantly less volatility than 100% stocks.

sections.title: Choosing the Right Mix
sections.content: Your asset allocation should reflect your time horizon, risk tolerance, and income needs. Younger investors often tilt toward stocks for growth, while those nearing retirement shift toward bonds and diversified funds to preserve capital. Funds make diversification easier because a single purchase spreads your investment across dozens or hundreds of holdings.

sections.title: Build Your Allocation
steps: List your investment goals and the time horizon for each.
Assign a risk score to yourself: conservative, balanced, or aggressive.
Draft a target allocation (for example, 60% broad-market ETF, 30% bond fund, 10% thematic fund).
Compare expense ratios and minimums for two funds that match your plan.

sections.title: Watch the Fees
sections.content: Expense ratios, trading commissions, and mutual fund load fees chip away at returns. Favor low-cost index ETFs for core holdings.
